PathSim: Similarity in Terms of Peers
Path count and Random walk (RW) Favor highly visible objects (objects with large degrees)
Pairwise random walk (PRW) Favor pure objects (objects with highly skewed scatterness in their in
links or out-links)
PathSim Favor peers (objects with similar visibility and strong connectivity
under the given meta path)

For IMDB network Find similar actors based on their movie style and productivity

The Top-K Similarity Search Problem under PathSim
Given an HIN and its network schema , given a round trip meta path , where , the top-k similarity search problem under PathSim is: for a query object , find the sorted k objects in the
same type that are most similar to , under PathSim similarity definition
Major Issues for Online Computation
Very large matrix multiplication Need to compute the commuting matrix
Calculate from scratch? Time expensive for online query processing
Fully materialization? Both time and space expensive
E.g., for DBLP network (~710K authors), the meta path APCPA will generate around 5 billion nonzero elements, which needs storage up to 40 G; longer meta path will cost storage for 4T easily
The Solution: Partial Materialization

Partially materialize commuting matrices for short length meta paths, and concatenate them online to get longer ones for a given query Materialize the commuting matrix for meta path ( for ): Concatenate them into or online for a given query by vector
matrix multiplication The form of concatenation will be discussed in the following
Two algorithms returning exact top-k results are proposed based on partial materialization PathSim-baseline PathSim-pruning

Co-clustering-based Pruning Algorithm
Intuition: prune the candidates that are not promising 1. Offline: Generate co-clusters according to partial commuting
matrix and store statistics for each block for deriving upper bound of similarity
Statistics include block sum, 1-norm and 2-norm for each row and column vectors
candidate cluster; prune the whole cluster if it is not promising 2. Calculate the upper bound similarity between query and each
candidate in the cluster; prune the candidate if it is not promising 3. Calculate the exact similarity measure between query and the
candidate, and update the top-k list
The Co-Clustering Algorithm on Parital Communting Matrix
Input: Communting Matrix ; number of row clusters U; number of column clusters V
Output: row clusters and column clusters Iterative algorithm
Fixing column clusters: get row centers and adjust row objects according to KL distance between row distribution and row cluster distribution
Fixing row clusters: get column centers and adjust column objects according to KL distance between column distribution and column cluster distribution
Time complexity O(t(m+n)UV)
m and n are number of row objects and column objects t is the number of iterations
